These 5 Countries Are the Biggest Plastic Polluters
Ocean plastic harms seabirds and other wildlife, and a recent report zeroes in on the top culprits.

By Suzanne Jacobs, Grist
January 21, 2016

There’s a veritable amount of plastic floating around in the world’s oceans—between 10 and 30 billion pounds of it, to be imprecise—and more than half of it comes from just five countries.

Those countries are China, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam, according to a report from the Ocean Conservancy and the McKinsey Center for Business and Environment. Here’s why these countries are on the hook for up to 60 percent of the world’s ocean plastic:

- As Asian economies rise, people have more cash to spend on various items. However, the garbage produced by these habits often doesn’t end up in proper landfills. In the five Asian countries listed above, only about 40 percent of garbage is properly collected. Trash is often piled up in communal dumps where stray bits are swept up by the wind and cast into the ocean. Even sanctioned garbage dump sites are sometimes intentionally set up near rivers that flow into the sea.

The situation would be even worse if not for the efforts of trash pickers—the courageous individuals who wade through garbage in search of valuable recyclables.

- Another part of the problem is that products are packaged differently in developing countries. Corporations in Asia sell everything from beauty products to instant noodles in tiny, cheap quantities, resulting in a lot more plastic packaging ending up in the ocean.

If the top plastic polluters don’t adopt proper waste management systems, and their demand for plastic-based consumer goods continues to grow, then by 2025 there could be one ton of plastic for every three tons of fish in the oceans, according to the report.

The article also emphasizes the importance of recycling and proper waste management, as well as the need for corporations to address the issue.

The full article provides more details on ocean plastics and their impact on seabirds, and it is available on Grist.
